{{for|the 2005 film|Adam & Steve}} {{for|the song by Dorian Electra|Flamboyant (album)}} {{Notability|talk=Notability|date=October 2019}} __NOTOC__ {{Wiktionary|Adam and Steve}}
"'''Adam and Steve'''" is a [[phrase]] that originated from the [[Social conservatism|conservative]] Christian slogan "God made [[Adam and Eve]], not Adam and Steve", intended to concisely summarize [[Judeo-Christian]] Bible-based arguments against [[gay sexual practices]] or [[homosexuality]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Clarke | first = Victoria | title = What about the children? arguments against lesbian and gay parenting | journal = [[Women's Studies International Forum]] | volume = 24 | issue = 5 | pages = 555–570 | doi = 10.1016/S0277-5395(01)00193-5 | date = September–October 2001 | ref = harv | url = http://eprints.uwe.ac.uk/21177/ }}</ref> The assumption behind this phrase is that the Biblical account of the [[Genesis (Bible)|creation]] of human beings as a male-female pair illustrates the natural or divinely-intended way of life for humanity. It occurs in some Christian right [[anti-LGBT rhetoric]].
== History == The phrase appeared, on a protest sign, as early as 1977, as mentioned in a ''New York Times'' news service report about a November 19 rally in Houston that year.<ref>{{cite news |last=Klemesrud |first=Judy |authorlink=Judy Lee Klemesrud |title=Equal Rights Plan and Abortion Are Opposed by 15,000 at Rally |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1977/11/20/archives/equal-rights-plan-and-abortion-are-opposed-by-15000-at-rally-like-a.html |work=New York Times |date=November 20, 1977 |accessdate=2008-12-26 }}</ref> The phrase was used in "The Gay Bar", an episode of ''[[Maude (TV series)|Maude]]'' broadcast on December 3, 1977. Two years later, [[Jerry Falwell]] gave the phrase wider circulation in a ''[[Christianity Today]]'' report of a press conference he had given.<ref>{{cite book | last = Balch | first = David | title = Homosexuality, science, and the "plain sense" of Scripture | publisher = Wm. B. Eerdmans | location = Grand Rapids, Mich | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-8028-4698-3 | page=22}}</ref> The phrase later acquired a certain notoriety, and, when used to name a pair of characters in a work of fiction, helps to identify them as members of a homosexual pair ([[Paul Rudnick]]'s play ''The Most Fabulous Story Ever Told'',<ref>{{cite news | last = Hurwitt | first = Robert | title = Adam and Steve's adventures in paradise | work = San Francisco Chronicle | page = E4 | date = 21 May 2001 | url = http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Adam-and-Steve-s-adventures-in-paradise-2919586.php }}</ref> the 2005 film ''[[Adam & Steve]]'' and other works). The phrase was used by the [[Democratic Unionist Party]] MP [[David Simpson (Northern Ireland politician)|David Simpson]] during the British [[House of Commons (UK)|House of Commons]]' [[Marriage (Same-Sex Couples) Bill|debate on same-sex marriage]], although a slip of the tongue originally saying "in the Garden of Eden, it was Adam and Steve" initially caused laughter in the chamber.<ref>{{cite news | last = Hennessy | first = Mark | title = British MPs back gay marriage legislation | work = The Irish Times | url = http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2013/0206/1224329707241.html | date = 6 February 2013 }}</ref>
==Variations and other languages== {{redirect|Madam and Eve|the comic strip|Madam & Eve}} The phrase "'''Madam and Eve'''" is sometimes used analogously in reference to [[lesbian]] relationships.
In [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]], the phrase is rendered as ''"Deus criou Adão e Eva, não Adão e Ivo".''
